docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some copies yesterday about employer efforts to provide free drugs to workers with chronic medical conditions misidentified the state in which one of the employers, Polk County, is located. It is in Florida, not Georgia.
docs.abstract: Correction; Feb 21 article about employer efforts to provide free drugs to workers with chronic conditions misidentified state of one employer; it is Florida, not Georgia
docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some copies yesterday about employer efforts to provide free drugs to workers with chronic medical conditions misidentified the state in which one of the employers, Polk County, is located. It is...

docs.lead_paragraph: IPHONE DISPUTE SETTLED Cisco Systems and Apple said they had settled the trademark-infringement lawsuit that threatened to derail Apple's use of the iPhone name for its much-hyped new cellular phone. [Page C1.] RATE RISE IN JAPAN The Japanese central bank doubled its benchmark overnight funds rate, to 0.5 percent. The bank's governor, Toshihiko Fukui, has said that he wants to raise rates, but the administration of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, above, has sent a clear message that it wants borrowing costs kept low. [C3.] LENDER REPORTS LOSS The toll is mounting for lenders that operate in the riskiest and, until recently, fastest-growing segment of the mortgage business. Shares of NovaStar Financial, which makes loans to people with weak credit, fell almost 43 percent after the company announced a surprise fourth-quarter loss of $14.4 million. [C1.] NATURAL-FOODS DEAL Stung by competition and investor expectations, Whole Foods Market, the natural-foods grocer, was expected to announce another quarter of rather mundane earnings. Instead, John P. Mackey, the chairman and chief executive, surprised investors by announcing a proposed merger with Wild Oats Markets. [C1.] REAL ESTATE AND REALITY The case of a relatively small development in Southwest Florida illustrates the important role that real estate investors played in driving a housing boom over the edge. [C1.] CHRYSLER ON THE BLOCK DaimlerChrysler would prefer to sell the struggling Chrysler Group in one piece, rather than let potential bidders pick and choose among its assets. Market Place. [C13.] HOSPITALS JOIN INSURANCE DEBATE Joining the national debate over the 47 million people without health insurance, a group of the nation's largest profit-making hospital chains plan to propose that individuals be required to have basic health coverage. [C2.] GOLDMAN BONUSES Goldman Sachs paid its co-presidents, Gary D. Cohn and Jon Winkelried, bonuses of about $52.5 million each for the 2006 fiscal year, the investment bank said in a regulatory filing. [C2.] INFLATION WATCH The Federal Reserve may expect more subdued inflation, but a small jump in January consumer prices was a reminder that those expectations are still far from being fulfilled. As a result, analysts said, the Fed may yet find itself raising interest rates. [C3.] STOCKS MIXED Inflation again commanded Wall Street's attention, with the latest readings leaving some investors unnerved. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.23 points, or 0.38 percent, to 12,738.41. [C15.] ELEVATOR MAKERS FINED European Union regulators fined the Otis Elevator division of United Technologies and four other elevator makers $1.3 billion for operating cartels for the installation and maintenance of elevators and escalators. [C13.] BIOTECH PATENT TO BE REVOKED The Patent and Trademark Office has decided to revoke a fundamental and controversial biotechnology patent held by Genentech. [C13.] SOFTWARE COMPANY FINED Securities regulators have fined Veritas Software $30 million to settle accusations that the company engaged in an assortment of accounting schemes in the years leading to its sale to Symantec in 2005. [C4.] CANDIDATE LIT The lineup of potential presidential candidates is a mishmash of senators, governors, former big-city mayors and a retired four-star Army general. But nearly all of them share one title: published author. [E1.] RUSSIAN BANK OFFERING Russia's state savings bank, Sberbank, was poised to raise $8.8 billion in a secondary stock offering, a government official said. The offering would be the second largest in Russian history, after that of the state-controlled oil company Rosneft. [C13.] JETBLUE EXPECTS WIDER LOSS JetBlue Airways said that it expected a wider first-quarter loss and lower full-year profit, as it absorbed the effect of more than 1,000 flight cancellations caused by winter weather in the Northeast. [C13.] CAFFEINE LABELS The Coca-Cola Company said that it would put caffeine content information on the labels of all of its drink products distributed in the United States that include the ingredient. [C6.] PARKING OPERATOR ACCEPTS BID The Central Parking Corporation, a parking lot operator, said it had accepted a takeover bid of about $733 million from a private equity consortium led by Kohlberg & Company. [C11.] A BETTER YARDSTICK Marketers are increasingly focused on the effectiveness of their pitches. And that is spurring most of the major media, along with many large research companies, to improve how they measure audiences. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C12.] ONLINE KEEP TABS ON THE CONTRACTOR For owners who live far from where their second homes are being built, contractors provide updates through personalized Web sites and detailed e-mail messages. A report is at nytimes.com/realestate. SELLING 5,881 HOMES In Brooklyn, residents are watchful as the Starrett City apartment complex is being sold. A slide show is at nytimes.com/nyregion. MOST POPULAR James Barron, a reporter at The New York Times, discusses the three most e-mailed articles on NYTimes.com every weekday. The podcast can be downloaded at nytimes.com/podcasts.
